awd_titl_txt: Development of a large-aperture coherent hydrophone array, data processing and analysis software system for instantaneous wide-area passive acoustic monitoring of marine mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop and provide high-resolution coherent hydrophone array hardware technology for compliance based marine mammal monitoring in support of seismic survey operations on UNOLs research vessels.  A large-aperture densely-sampled hydrophone array system can provide significant enhancement in marine mammal vocalization detection by increasing signal-to-noise ratio via coherent beamforming which eliminates noise outside of the signal beam.  Whale vocalizations not detected using a single hydrophone or sparse array can be extracted out of the noise floor by coherent beamforming with the large aperture hydrophone array system.  The coherent beamforming also provides high-resolution estimates of whale vocalization bearings which are required for finding the range of the whale from the array and localizing the marine mammal in geographic space.  In addition to the array hardware, the project also aims to develop a real-time array signal data acquisition, processing and analysis software to provide real-time detection, bearing-estimation, localization and tracking, and classification of marine mammal vocalizations received on the coherent hydrophone array hardware system.  The hardware and software systems together make up the passive ocean acoustic waveguide remote sensing (POAWRS) technology.

POAWRS is a transformative approach for ocean sensing, since it is capable of monitoring sound sources over instantaneous wide areas spanning 100 km or more in diameter.  In addition to marine mammal vocalizations, the other sound sources detected by POAWRS include biology such as sounds from fish and crustaceans; geophysical processes such as hurricanes and submarine volcanoes; and man-made activities such as ships and other ocean vehicles, seismic airgun and sparker for earthquake plate tectonic studies and oil exploration, as well as offshore piling. The instantaneous continental-shelf scale environmental monitoring capability and temporal-spatial dynamics of sound sources revealed by POAWRS makes it an important technology that could become an indispensable tool in field operations, such as large-scale marine ecological studies, fisheries stock assessments and management, compliance-based marine mammal monitoring mandated by the Marine Mammal Protection Act in seismic surveys and naval sonar surveillance operations, as well as in studies of the effects of man-made sound on marine ecosystems.  When combined with an active acoustic or seismic source, such as on the RV Langseth, the proposed instrumentation can be extended for large-scale imaging of objects and features in geophysical, fisheries, ecological and archeological surveys. The project provides an opportunity for training and development work to a diverse team that includes both women and under-represented minorities.  The principal investigator has and will continue to host and provide opportunities for K-12 students, undergraduates and teachers to learn and contribute to ocean exploration and discovery through Northeastern University's STEM Education Center, Research Experience for Teachers (RET), Young Scholars Program (YSP) and various undergraduate research opportunity programs.  They have and will continue to visit elementary, middle and high schools to provide demonstrations and hands-on training in ocean discovery and sensing through ocean sounds.

por.por_cntn:
We have designed, developed and fabricated a 160-element coherent hydrophone array hardware system and associated array data processing and analysis computing system inhouse at Northeastern University (NU). The coherent hydrophone array system provides real-time directional and instantaneous wide-area monitoring of ocean sound producers via the Passive Ocean Acoustic Waveguide Remote Sensing (POAWRS) technique in frequency range from 10 Hz to 50,000 Hz (or 50 kHz). The array system was demonstrated at sea in the US Northeast coast in Fall 2021, deployed in both shallow water Great South Channel, and continental-slope and deep ocean south of Rhode Island. A total of 101 hours of coherent hydrophone array undersea acoustic data were acquired, including several continuous 12 hour to 24 hour recording intervals over 6 days of sea time. The sound sources monitored in real-time include ocean biology, such as marine mammal vocalizations and fish sounds from diverse species; man-made activities, such as distant ship tonal and broadband sounds; as well as geophysical processes, such as undersea wind generated noise. Image 2 shows photos of the NU coherent hydrophone array system deployed on RV Endeavor for the sea test, while Image 3 shows the array schematics. The NU coherent hydrophone array system consists of 160 hydrophone elements nested into four subapertures; forward and aft non-acoustic sensor sections for array depth, heading and orientation measurement; a vibration isolation module to dampen flow noise; a 600 m long tow cable with ethernet fiber-optic and power copper conducters; a winch for array handling; as well as shipboard data archival hub and high performance computing workstations with hardware and software accelerations for real-time array data processing and analysis. The coherent hydrophone array instrumentation development involved (i) acoustic modeling and analysis to ensure appropriate array sensitivity and dynamic range for capturing the wide intensity range of underwater sounds, (ii) hydrophone transducer design and specification with respect to sensitivity, size and frequency response, (iii) power distribution system design and implementation, (iv) pressure tolerant electronics, such as preamplifier and power PCB design, testing and fabrication, (v) integration, synchronization and testing of data acquisition analog-to-digital converter systems, (vi) non-acoustic depth and orientation sensor setup and integration, (vii) mechanical array aperture interconnect design and fabrication, (viii) array component packaging and oil filling in array tubing, (ix) shipboard data archival and real-time array data processing computing hardware configuration and assembly, and (x) array signal processing and analysis computational acceleration and enhancement for 100 kHz sampled array data. The array sampling frequency is roughly ten times higher than what was originally proposed, making the array highly versatile, for instance, enabling small toothed whale vocalizations, such as dolphin whistles and echolocation clicks, to be detected simultaneously with large baleen whale calls, such as fin whale 20 Hz pulses. Images 1 and 4-6 show beamformed spectrograms containing marine mammal vocalizations generated at sea in the Great South Channel. Beamforming with subapertures of the array significantly enhance the signal-to-noise ratio of detected marine mammal vocalizations by a factor of 10 to 20 dB (Images 1 and 4). Beamforming enhances signal detection ranges by one to two orders of magnitude over that of a single hydrophone and also provides estimates of signal bearing needed for object localization.

 

POAWRS is a transformative approach for ocean sensing, since it is capable of monitoring sound sources in real time over instantaneous wide areas spanning 100 km or more in diameter via a large-aperture coherent hydrophone array. This project has enabled the POAWRS technology to become available to the ocean science community for real-time ocean monitoring in a wide range of fields and applications. These include large-scale marine ecological studies, fisheries stock assessments and ocean resource management, compliance-based marine mammal monitoring mandated by the Marine Mammal Protection Act in offshore energy prospecting that includes hydrocarbons and wind farms, as well as maritime surveillance. When combined with an active acoustic or seismic source, the proposed instrumentation can be extended for large-scale imaging of ocean objects, such as large fish shoal instantaneous temporospatial distributions and dynamics, and geological features. For outreach, we have created a website providing information about the array, including sample array data recordings and imagery from our sea experiment, see link below. In addition, we have also presented the availability of the array for real-time ocean monitoring and research to Program Managers at NSF, ONR, and BOEM, as well as colleagues at numerous conferences including AGU Oceans, IEEE Oceans and the Acoustical Society of America Meeting. This project advances multidisciplinary science and engineering areas of electrical, mechanical, computer and ocean engineering, ocean acoustics, statistical physics, ocean biology, ecology, oceanography and geophysical sciences, machine learning and data mining. The NU 160-element coherent hydrophone array system enables ocean discoveries to be made "on-the-fly" at sea and provides real-time feedback for optimizing ocean observation and data collection.

 

https://ece.northeastern.edu/fac-ece/purnima/NUarray.html

 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Purnima R Makris

    Northeastern University Laboratory for Ocean Acoustics and Ecosystem Sensing
